headers.full: The Ordering Structure of the Real Numbers System
headers.toc: The Ordering Structure of the Real Numbers System

intro.para: In this section we introduce axioms which ensure that we have a size comparison of any two real numbers. These are the ordering axioms of \RNr. We then discuss the main properties of this ordering structure.

def.caption: Ordering structure of real numbers

info.caption: Comment
info.para: These properties say that \RNr is a totally ordered set.

def.para:
There is a set of ordered pairs (x,y)\in\RNr[2] satisfying the relationship
x\leq y
Read this as: ‘x is less than or equal to y.’
with the following properties.

li.para: Reflexivity: x\leq x for all x\in \RNr.
Transitivity: if x\leq y and y\leq z, then x\leq z, for all x,y,z\in \RNr.
Antisymmetry: if x\leq y and y\leq x, then x=y, for all x,y\in \RNr.
Totality: for all x,y\in \RNr, x\leq y or y\leq x.

def.para: Based on the ordering axioms or \RNr, we adopt the following conventions

li.para:
We say y\geq x
Read: ‘y is greater than or equal to x.’
if x\leq y.

We also say
x < y
Read this as: ‘x is less than y’ or ‘x is strictly less than y’.
if x\leq y and \neq y. Equivalently, we say
y > x
Read this as: ‘y is greater than x’ or ‘y is strictly greater than x’.
.

We say that x\in \RNr is positive if x > 0 .

We say that y\in \RNr is negative if y < 0 .

section.body.para: Addition and multiplication in \RNr are required to be compatible with the ordering structure by the axioms below.

def.caption: Compatibility with addition and multiplication
def.para: For all x,y,z\in \RNr the following hold:

li.para: If x < y , then x+z < y+z .
If 0 < x and 0 < y , then 0 < x\cdot y .
